dn15:9.1.pli: Iti kho panetaṁ, ānanda, vedanaṁ paṭicca taṇhā, taṇhaṁ paṭicca pariyesanā, pariyesanaṁ paṭicca lābho, lābhaṁ paṭicca vinicchayo, vinicchayaṁ paṭicca chandarāgo, chandarāgaṁ paṭicca ajjhosānaṁ, ajjhosānaṁ paṭicca pariggaho, pariggahaṁ paṭicca macchariyaṁ, macchariyaṁ paṭicca ārakkho.
dn15:9.1.en: So it is, Ānanda, that feeling is a cause of craving. Craving is a cause of seeking. Seeking is a cause of gaining material possessions. Gaining material possessions is a cause of [38;5;121massess[0ming. [38;5;121mAssess[0ming is a cause of desire and lust. Desire and lust is a cause of attachment. Attachment is a cause of possessiveness. Possessiveness is a cause of stinginess. Stinginess is a cause of safeguarding.

dn15:15.1.pli: ‘Vinicchayaṁ paṭicca chandarāgo’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā vinicchayaṁ paṭicca chandarāgo.
dn15:15.1.en: ‘[38;5;121mAssess[0ming is a cause of desire and lust’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.

dn15:15.2.pli: Vinicchayo ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, sabbaso vinicchaye asati vinicchayanirodhā api nu kho chandarāgo paññāyethā”ti?
dn15:15.2.en: Suppose there were totally and utterly no [38;5;121massess[0ming for anyone anywhere. When there’s no [38;5;121massess[0ming at all, with the cessation of [38;5;121massess[0ming, would desire and lust still be found?”

dn15:15.4.pli: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo chandarāgassa, yadidaṁ vinicchayo.
dn15:15.4.en: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of desire and lust, namely [38;5;121massess[0ming.

dn15:16.1.pli: ‘Lābhaṁ paṭicca vinicchayo’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā lābhaṁ paṭicca vinicchayo.
dn15:16.1.en: ‘Gaining material possessions is a cause of [38;5;121massess[0ming’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.

dn15:16.2.pli: Lābho ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, sabbaso lābhe asati lābhanirodhā api nu kho vinicchayo paññāyethā”ti?
dn15:16.2.en: Suppose there were totally and utterly no gaining of material possessions for anyone anywhere. When there’s no gaining of material possessions at all, with the cessation of gaining material possessions, would [38;5;121massess[0ming still be found?”

dn15:16.4.pli: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo vinicchayassa, yadidaṁ lābho.
dn15:16.4.en: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of [38;5;121massess[0ming, namely the gaining of material possessions.

mn139:3.5.en: Know how to [38;5;121massess[0m different kinds of pleasure.

mn139:9.1.en: ‘Know how to [38;5;121massess[0m different kinds of pleasure.

an6.44:5.1.pli: “Kā cānanda, migasālā upāsikā bālā abyattā ammakā ammakapaññā, ke ca purisapuggalaparopariyañāṇe?
an6.44:5.1.en: “Ānanda, who is this laywoman Migasālā, a foolish incompetent matron, with an matron’s wit? And who is it that knows how to [38;5;121massess[0m individuals?

an6.44:17.1.pli: Kā cānanda, migasālā upāsikā bālā abyattā ammakā ammakapaññā, ke ca purisapuggalaparopariyañāṇe.
an6.44:17.1.en: Who is this laywoman Migasālā, a foolish incompetent matron, with a matron’s wit? And who is it that knows how to [38;5;121massess[0m individuals?

an10.75:8.1.pli: “Kā cānanda, migasālā upāsikā bālā abyattā ammakā ammakapaññā, ke ca purisapuggalaparopariye ñāṇe?
an10.75:8.1.en: “Ānanda, who is this laywoman Migasālā, a foolish incompetent matron, with a matron’s wit? And who is it that knows how to [38;5;121massess[0m individuals?

an10.75:26.1.pli: Kā cānanda, migasālā upāsikā bālā abyattā ammakā ammakapaññā, ke ca purisapuggalaparopariye ñāṇe.
an10.75:26.1.en: Who is this laywoman Migasālā, a foolish incompetent matron, with a matron’s wit? And who is it that knows how to [38;5;121massess[0m individuals?

an9.23:1.3.pli: Taṇhaṁ paṭicca pariyesanā, pariyesanaṁ paṭicca lābho, lābhaṁ paṭicca vinicchayo, vinicchayaṁ paṭicca chandarāgo, chandarāgaṁ paṭicca ajjhosānaṁ, ajjhosānaṁ paṭicca pariggaho, pariggahaṁ paṭicca macchariyaṁ, macchariyaṁ paṭicca ārakkho, ārakkhādhikaraṇaṁ daṇḍādānaṁ satthādānaṁ kalahaviggahavivādatuvaṁtuvaṁpesuññamusāvādā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
an9.23:1.3.en: Craving is a cause for seeking. Seeking is a cause for gaining material possessions. Gaining material possessions is a cause for [38;5;121massess[0ming. [38;5;121mAssess[0ming is a cause for desire and lust. Desire and lust is a cause for attachment. Attachment is a cause for possessiveness. Possessiveness is a cause for stinginess. Stinginess is a cause for safeguarding. Owing to safeguarding, many bad, unskillful things come to be: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, and fights, accusations, divisive speech, and lies.

an5.48:8.2.en: as they’re able to [38;5;121massess[0m what’s beneficial,

an5.50:15.2.en: as they’re able to [38;5;121massess[0m what’s beneficial,

dn34:2.2.32.pli: taṇhaṁ paṭicca pariyesanā, pariyesanaṁ paṭicca lābho, lābhaṁ paṭicca vinicchayo, vinicchayaṁ paṭicca chandarāgo, chandarāgaṁ paṭicca ajjhosānaṁ, ajjhosānaṁ paṭicca pariggaho, pariggahaṁ paṭicca macchariyaṁ, macchariyaṁ paṭicca ārakkho, ārakkhādhikaraṇaṁ daṇḍādānasatthādānakalahaviggahavivādatuvaṁtuvaṁpesuññamusāvādā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
dn34:2.2.32.en: Craving is a cause for seeking. Seeking is a cause for gaining material possessions. Gaining material possessions is a cause for [38;5;121massess[0ming. [38;5;121mAssess[0ming is a cause for desire and lust. Desire and lust is a cause for attachment. Attachment is a cause for possessiveness. Possessiveness is a cause for stinginess. Stinginess is a cause for safeguarding. Owing to safeguarding, many bad, unskillful things come to be: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, fights, accusations, divisive speech, and lies.
